Project Description  The Government has identified the 1,000-megawatt (MW) Mong 
  Duong 1 Thermal Power Project (the Project) as a priority power 
  generation project for meeting the country’s rapidly growing power 
  demand.  A  least-cost  power  generation  option,  the  Project  is 
  included in the 6th Power Development Master Plan (2006–2015) 
  with an outlook until 2025. The Project involves building a 1,000 
  MW  coal-fired  thermal  power  generating  station  that  uses 
  circulating fluidized bed (CFB) boiler technology—a “cleaner coal” 
  technology. The Project is scheduled to be commissioned in 2012. 
  Common facilities for the next phase of the power plant also are 
  included within the project scope. These facilities will support the 
  expansion of Mong Duong thermal power complex through the 
construction  of  the  1,000–1,200  MW  Mong  Duong  2  thermal 
power project, which is being formulated. The private sector will 
build the Mong Duong 2, which is aimed for commissioning by 
2013, under a build-operate-transfer arrangement. The Project will 
also  provide  appropriate  institutional  and  technical  capacity 
building, particularly in CFB boiler technology and operation.   
   
Rationale  Viet Nam’s economy has been growing at about 7.5% a year over 
the past decade, with gross domestic product (GDP) growth in 
2006 reaching 8.2%. The Government is determined to maintain 
the high economic growth of 8%–8.5% in the country’s 5-year 
socioeconomic  development  plan  (for  2006–2010)  to  reduce 
poverty to 11%–15% by 2010. To sustain this economic growth, a 
reliable supply of electricity is essential, as electricity is central to 
almost  every  aspect  of  Viet  Nam’s  sustainable  socioeconomic 
development:  job  creation,  industrial  activities,  commerce  and 
businesses, and other drivers of economic growth and people’s 
well-being. Following Viet Nam’s accession to the World Trade 
Organization  (WTO)  in  2007,  foreign  direct  investment  and 
domestic  investment  have  increased  substantially,  with  new 
businesses being established at an ever-increasing rate.  
 
The  Government’s  updated  Sixth  Power  Development  Master 
Plan (2006–2015) envisages power demand to grow at 16% per

ii     
year until 2011, and at 11% per year thereafter until 2015. This 
might prove to be conservative, since power demand growth over 
the first quarter of 2007 has been about 20% The drivers of this 
demand—rapid industrialization, establishment of industrial zones, 
increasing  foreign  direct  investment,  and  increasing  trade 
following  WTO  accession—show  little  sign  of  diminishing. 
Reflecting this rapidly increasing demand, which is fast outpacing 
the country’s generation capacity, Viet Nam is experiencing power 
outages, and these will increase unless new generation capacity 
is added quickly.  
 
The  high  growth  rate  in  electricity  demand,  coupled  with  the 
country’s disproportionate dependency on hydropower, has left 
Viet  Nam  with  dangerously  low  reserves  during  annual  dry 
seasons, when limited river flows reduce hydropower output to 
about 40%–50% of rated output. Without significant increases in 
thermal  plant  generation  capacity,  the  continuing  demand  for 
electricity would reduce system reserve capacity to zero by 2010. 
Viet Nam Electricity (EVN), therefore, plans to develop thermal 
power plants urgently based on coal, including Mong Duong 1, to 
address system imbalances and seasonal generation shortages.  
 
The Government has made a policy decision to use domestic and 
imported coal to ensure security of electricity supply. Under the 
updated 6th Power Development Master Plan, coal power plants 
are to provide for essential base-load power generation. Coal’s 
share in the country’s generation mix will more than double from 
16% (in 2006) to 34% in 2020, while the share of hydropower will 
fall gradually from 37% in 2006 to 27% in 2020. Nevertheless, 
hydropower  will  remain  the  second  largest  component  in  the 
generation capacity mix. The proposed Project is in Quang Ninh 
Province  of  northern  Viet  Nam,  where  coal  is  abundant—
accounting for 90% of the country’s coal reserves. Viet Nam is a 
signatory to the Kyoto Protocol, though it is not required to reduce 
carbon emissions under the agreement, which lasts until 2012.  
 
The  2005  United  Nations  Framework  Convention  on  Climate 
Change shows that Viet Nam emits 0.3 tons of carbon dioxide 
(CO ) per capita, compared with 6.3 tons per capita by Japan, 8.8 
2
tons per capita by the United Kingdom, and 20.6 tons per capita 
by  the  United  States  of  America.  As  Viet  Nam’s  economy 
develops, its consumption of energy will increase to sustain the 
economic growth and reduce poverty to 15%. In this context, Viet 
Nam is aware that the country’s CO  emissions will increase, and 
2
is using clean coal technologies in power generation to reduce 
CO  emissions. 
2
 
In  recognizing  its  fiscal  constraints  to  meet  all  investment 
demands  for  infrastructure  development,  the  Government 
requested  assistance  from  ADB  in  developing  a  new  thermal 
power  generation  project  in  2007,  in  the  northern  part  of  the 
country to meet the country’s growing demand for electricity. The

iii 
Asian Development Bank’s 2005 Country Strategy and Program 
Update  for  Viet  Nam  included  a  project  preparatory  technical 
assistance (TA) in 2007 to prepare a second power generation 
project and an investment loan in 2008 to finance a portion of the 
power generation project. To bring the investment loan forward a 
TA1 was provided in 2005. An ADB appraisal mission visited Viet 
Nam in August 2006 and this report is based on the agreements 
reached during the mission. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The Project will foster sustainable national economic growth, and 
generate employment. Expanding power generation capacity and 
providing reliable power supplies will support the Government’s 
efforts to accelerate poverty reduction. Improving the reliability of 
the  power  supply  during  the  dry  season  will  ensure  a  stable 
supply of electricity to meet the growing demand of industrial, 
commercial, residential, and rural consumers, preventing further 
load  shedding. 2  The  Project  will  also  address  the  current 
imbalance between hydropower and thermal generation capacity 
in the power system by increasing base-load thermal generation. 
Further, the Project will support private sector development in the 
power  sector.  By  financing  the  required  common  facilities  for 
Mong Duong 2, the Project permits EVN to award that project on a 
stand-alone basis for private sector participatory development.

Multitranche Financing  The  Government  has  requested  adoption  of  a  multitranche 
Facility Amount and  financing facility (MFF), under ADB’s Pilot Financing Instruments 
Terms  and Modalities, for $930.71 million over 6 years. This represents 
84.6%  of  total  project  financing  costs.  In  particular,  the 
Government has requested the ADB financing in two loans under 
the MFF. The first requested loan under the MFF is for $27.86 
million, while the second is expected to be for the balance of 
$902.85  million.  In  accordance  with  ADB’s  Pilot  Financing 
Instruments and Modalities, the Government will submit signed 
periodic financing requests (PFR) to ADB, which will trigger the 
subsequent loan. The Government has agreed to enter into a 
framework financing agreement (FFA) with ADB. This agreement 
is in a form consistent with the requirements of Appendix 4 of 
ADB’s Pilot Financing Instruments and Modalities. Pursuant to the 
FFA, the Government will submit to ADB a PFR for $27.86 million 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources (OCR). The form of this 
PFR for the first loan is presented to the Board along with the 
FFA. Before accepting the subsequent PFR, ADB will ensure that 
the  Government  and  EVN  fully  comply  with  the  terms  and 
conditions of the FFA. ADB missions will conduct due diligence on 
these to ensure that they are being adhered to satisfactorily.  
 
The  Government  selected  two  loans  under  the  MFF  as  its 
preferred mode of financing for the Project, rather than adopting a 
traditional project loan, largely due to (i) the loan being almost $1 
billion, when only about $27.86 million is needed in the first 2 
years; (ii) the need for sufficient time to design, bid, negotiate, and 
award  the  main  engineering,  procurement,  and  construction 
(EPC)  contract  to  a  suitable  contractor  (to  be  selected  under 
international competitive bidding, following ADB guidelines); and 
(iii) apprehension that bids for the EPC contract could escalate 
unless the bidding community sees that financing is firmly in place 
beforehand.

v 
 
The initial loan of $27.86 million will be used for (i) procurement of 
civil works to prepare the site for the Mong Duong 1 thermal 
power  plant,  which  includes  leveling  of  the  project  site,  river 
diversion  works,  and  supply  of  equipment  for  constructing  a 
transmission  line  for  power  supply;  (ii)  consulting  services  for 
reviewing  and  updating  the  technical  designs  and  drawings, 
preparing  bid  documents  for  selection  of  the  EPC  contractor, 
assisting EVN in contract negotiations, and supervising the civil 
works contracts under item (i); and (iii) consulting services for 
updating  the  environmental  management  plan,  updating  the 
resettlement plan, and supervising their implementation. The site 
leveling works and river diversion works will take about 20 months 
to complete. During this period, EVN will undertake bidding and 
selection  of  an  EPC  contractor,  and  then  proceed  to  contract 
negotiations  and  contract  award.  Also  during  this  period,  the 
consultants  will  assist  EVN  in  updating  the  environmental 
management plan and resettlement plan, and will supervise their 
implementation.  Given  the  uncertainty  of  timing  in  such  large 
contract  negotiations,  the  Government  prudently  has  opted  to 
defer the second, larger loan to avoid payment of commitment 
fees over a long period. Hence, the timing of the second loan is 
targeted for when the EPC contractor has been selected and the 
EPC contract is substantially ready for award. 
 
Each loan will have a repayment period of 25 years. The first loan 
will have a grace period of 6 years, while the second will have a 4-
year  grace  period.  The  interest  rate  will  be  determined  in 
accordance with ADB’s London Interbank Offered Rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility. The Government can choose from eligible 
currencies and the interest rate regime most suitable for each 
loan.  ADB  also  provides  flexibility  in  terms  of  repayment  and 
interest rate swaps during the financing period. The Borrower will 
be the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam.

Terms  available  to  EVN  subject  to  the  terms  of  the  subsidiary  loan

Procurement  Equipment and materials to be financed under the MFF will be

vi     
procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines. 
International competitive bidding (ICB) will be used for (i) the EPC 
contract  of  the  power  plant  and  common  facilities,  (ii)  supply 
contracts estimated to cost the equivalent of $1.0 million or more, 
and (iii) civil works contracts valued at more than $3.0 million. 
National competitive bidding (NCB) or limited international bidding 
will be used for supply contracts less than $1.0 million. Civil works 
contracts  estimated  at  less  than  $3.0  million  will  be  procured 
following  NCB  procedures  acceptable  to  ADB.  Miscellaneous 
goods  and  civil  works  contracts  less  than  $100,000  will  be 
procured using shopping procedures. Contract packages will be 
prepared  to  ensure  maximum  competition  under  ICB.  Similar 
contractual  arrangements  and  specifications  will  be  applied  to 
other subprojects.  
   
Consulting Services  The Government has requested advance action for recruitment of 
consultants,  who  will  prepare  the  bidding  documents  for 
recruitment of the EPC contractor and civil works contracts, to 
allow site preparation works to begin promptly. In August 2006, 
ADB  Management  approved  advance  action  for  consultants. 
Consulting services will be required to (i) review technical designs, 
(ii) prepare bid documents for the EPC contract, (iii) supervise site 
preparation  civil  works,  (iv)  update  the  resettlement  plan  and 
monitor  its  implementation,  (v)  update  the  environmental 
management plan and monitor its implementation, (vi) conduct a 
socioeconomic  impact  assessment  of  the  health  situation,  (vii) 
monitor  project  performance,  and  (viii)  supervise  the  EPC 
contractor.  EVN  will  select  and  engage  the  consultants  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
Consulting  firms,  chosen  in  international  competition  using  the 
quality-and cost-based selection method, will provide the services. 
Individual  experts  may  be  recruited  based  on  curriculum  vitae 
submitted  in  response  to  specific  terms  of  reference  for  the 
assignment.  Two  recruitments  of  consulting  services  will  be 
undertaken for the Project. The first recruitment will be to assist 
EVN with (i) reviewing the bid documents for selection of the EPC 
contract,  and  subsequent  negotiations  and  award  of  the  EPC 
contract; (ii) reviewing civil works bid documents, followed by the 
bidding, awarding of contract, and supervision of civil works; (iii) 
updating the environmental management plan and resettlement 
plan; and (iv) supervising the environmental management plan 
and resettlement plan. EVN completed short-listing of consultants 
for  the  first  recruitment  in  June  2007  and  submitted  the  draft 
request  for  proposal  to  ADB  in  July  2007  for  approval.  The 
request for proposals will be issued in August 2007. The second 
consultant  recruitment  will  assist  EVN  with  the  overall 
management of the Project, supervision of the EPC contract and 
civil  works  contracts,  and  continued  monitoring  of  EMP 
implementation. Consulting inputs will total 820 person-months, 
comprising 556 person-months of international consulting services 
and 264 person-months of national consulting services.

vii 
Disbursements  The proceeds of individual loans under the MFF will be disbursed 
in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook  and 
ADB’s Interim Guidelines for Disbursement Operations, LIBOR-
Based Loan Products, both as amended from time to time. 
   
Project Benefits and  The construction of the 1,000 MW Mong Duong 1 power plant, 
Beneficiaries  together with site preparation and the common facilities for Mong 
Duong 2, will provide reliable electricity supply throughout the year 
in northern Viet Nam. The main beneficiaries of the Project will be 
the  industrial,  commercial,  residential,  and  rural  consumers  in 
northern  Viet  Nam.  Indirectly,  consumers  will  benefit  from 
improved  system  frequency  and  the  elimination  of  voltage 
fluctuations,  resulting  in  better  performance  and  longer  life  of 
electrical equipment. EVN will not have to resort to load shedding, 
which will support the development of the northeast region, where 
numerous industrial estates are established. The stable supply of 
electricity to northern Viet Nam will stimulate economic growth, 
and increase employment and income-earning opportunities for 
the  poor.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)  of  the 
Project is estimated at 22.5%. The financial internal rate of return 
(FIRR) is estimated at 7.5%, which is higher that the 2.97% real 
weighted average cost of capital. The Project will also generate 
direct employment in the project area through construction of the 
Mong  Duong  power  complex,  incremental  coal  mining,  and 
limestone mining activities. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  Project  is  not  expected  to  be  subject  to  any  significant 
technical risks. EVN has proven experience, and has performed 
well  in  implementing  internationally  financed  power  projects. 
Capacity building of EVN technical staff under the Project will 
improve operational knowledge and skills regarding CFB boiler 
technology. The financial and economic robustness of the Project 
has been evaluated, taking into consideration possible variations 
of key parameters. The main factors that might pose risks to the 
financial and economic viability of the Project are (i) lower demand 
for  electricity,  resulting  in  less  production  and  sales  from  the 
Project; (ii) higher-than-expected construction costs; (iii) possible 
delays in tariff increases; and (iv) delays in project construction, 
compared with the planned schedule. 
 
To evaluate these risks, financial and economic analyses were 
conducted using various scenarios, including reduced production 
or sale of electricity by up to 20%, higher project costs by up to 
10%,  and  delayed  project  implementation  by  1  year.  For 
combinations of theses scenarios, the EIRR and FIRR still meet 
acceptable criteria.  In addition,  sector  analysis  shows  that  the 
demand  for  electricity  is  unlikely  to  fall  significantly.  The 
Government has committed to gradually increasing tariffs to cover 
long-run  marginal  production  costs.  In  October  2006,  the 
Government approved an increase of 8.8% in the average tariff, 
which took effect on 1 January 2007.

viii    
The social risks include resettlement, possible spread of HIV/AIDS 
during construction, possible human trafficking, and deteriorating 
health  conditions  after  plant  operation.  Appropriate  mitigation 
measures  are  in  place  in  the  resettlement  plan  for  increasing 
awareness and implementing preventive measures for the local 
communities. Technical assistance is being formulated that will 
assist EVN in preparing an environmental action plan to improve 
pollution control and environmental management of thermal power 
plants.  The  technical  assistance  will  also  help  build  the 
institutional  capacity  of  the  project  province’s  Department  of 
Natural Resources and Environment on air quality management to 
minimize air pollution impacts from thermal power projects in the 
province. It will also assist in establishing baseline data for air 
quality monitoring in the project’ vicinity. 
 
A  possible  risk  is  that  the  Project  could  be  completed  under 
financing provided by parties that do not require ADB’s safeguard 
policies  to  be  applied  to  the  EPC  contract  for  the  Project. 
However, ADB’s strong and successful relationship with EVN, and 
its satisfactory and responsible performance in earlier projects, 
mitigates this risk considerably. 
 
Additional  analysis  was  carried  out  to  examine  the  possible 
impacts of a large investment such as this on the country's overall 
debt  sustainability  and  macroeconomic  situation.  The  analysis 
shows that the Mong Duong 1 investment does not alter the debt 
sustainability of the country in the medium to long term, because 
the disbursement of the loan is well within the annual OCR limit. 
The Project will not have significant effects on the prices of goods 
and services supplied to the Project. Further, it will not affect 
domestic inflation, because more than 70% of the ADB loan will 
be allocated to the EPC contractor, which will import most of the 
required  equipment.  Finally,  Mong  Duong  1  is  a  revenue-
generating project that will comfortably generate sufficient income 
to repay its associated loans.

A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Macroeconomic Performance  
 
2.  Viet Nam’s gross domestic product (GDP) has grown on average about 7.5% a year 
over the past decade. This strong economic growth has enabled the country to reduce poverty 
from 58% of the population in 1993 to 20% in 2006, while increasing per capita income from 
$288 to $644 in the same period. Viet Nam’s Socio-economic Development Plan 2006–2010, 
which was endorsed at the 10th Party Congress in April 2006, envisages reducing poverty to 
10%–11%, increasing per capita income to about $1,100, and doubling GDP by 2010. This 
implies annual GDP growth of 7.5%–8% during that period. In this context, the Socio-economic 
Development  Plan  emphasizes  the  role  of  physical  infrastructure1 in  increasing  national 
competitiveness  and  market  access,  and  attracting  investments  needed  to  sustain  strong 
economic  growth  and  poverty  reduction.  The  plan  also  stresses  the  importance  of  good 
governance,  private  sector  participation,  and  integration  with  the  global  economy  through 
membership in the World Trade Organization. The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) country 
strategy  and  program  (CSP)  for  2007–20102 supports  the  main  objectives  of  the  Socio-
economic  Development  Plan.  These  include  achieving  a  balance  between  businesses-led 
economic  growth,  social  equity,  and  environment  sustainability,  while  strengthening  the 
governance of public sector institutions and supporting private sector investments in productive 
sectors  of  the  economy.  The  CSP  highlights  the  importance  of  removing  infrastructure 
bottlenecks in the power and transport sectors to increase the competitiveness of Viet Nam’s 
private sector-led manufacturing and service sectors.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  ADB’s Sector Strategy  
10.  ADB’s approach has been to provide financial and institutional support for power sector 
development to help the Government achieve its development objectives. ADB’s development 
assistance strategy has focused on (i) expanding and strengthening the country’s high-voltage 
transmission  backbone  network;  (ii)  developing  least-cost  generation  projects  (hydro  and 
thermal) to meet growing power demand; (iii) promoting financial and fiscal sustainability by 
unbundling EVN into generation, transmission, and distribution companies that can operate as 
commercially viable and financially independent entities; (iv) creating an enabling environment 
for  private  sector  participation  in  a  competitive  power  market  in  Viet  Nam;  (v) promoting 
renewable  energy  sources  for  power  generation  in  rural  areas;  and  (vi) promoting  power 
interconnections in the Greater Mekong Subregion to allow power trading within the region by 
using the difference in peak load demand, and taking advantage of the spare capacities within 
high-voltage power transmission networks. Within ADB, the public sector and private sector staff 
have cooperated closely to support the development of public-private partnerships in the power 
sector, such as promoting the partnership to develop Mong Duong 1 and 2 projects jointly.11 
Further, ADB has engaged the Government in policy dialogue to improve sector performance. 
As  a  result,  the  Government  has  agreed  with  ADB  on  the  road  map  for  the  sector 
(Supplementary Appendix A), which includes Mong Duong 1 and 2. 
 
11.  ADB has approved $663.3 million in sovereign loans (Appendix 3) to develop the sector. 
The earlier loans were for strengthening the high-voltage transmission backbone networks in 
northern Viet Nam; and extending and rehabilitating medium- and low-voltage substations and 
distribution networks in the northern, central, and southern regions of the country. In addition, 
ADB has supported private sector investment in power generation through its Private Sector 
Operations Department. In the past 4 years, ADB has participated in the financing of two 
significant gas-fired thermal power plants at Phu My. In policy dialogue with the Government, 
ADB has prioritized the promotion of efficient use of energy, especially in the industrial sector. 
ADB will provide technical assistance (TA) to determine the potential for accessing the carbon 
market through renewable energy and industrial energy efficiency projects. Further, ADB will 
assess the possibility of accessing debt financing from domestic financing institutions to address 
these  issues  through  appropriately  designed  lending  or  guarantee  products  and  policy 
interventions, using ADB’s proposed Energy Efficiency Fund and Carbon Market Fund. 
 
12.  The Government and EVN recognize that the needs of the power sector cannot be met 
from domestic and public sector borrowings. Consequently, the Government initiated sector 
reforms starting in 2004 following an ADB-financed TA on power sector reforms.12 Under the

2.  Meeting the Rapid Growth in Power Demand 
13.  The main challenge facing the power sector is maintaining adequate investments to 
meet the exceptionally rapid growth in electricity demand. More than 49,000 MW in additional 
power generation capacity is projected for 2006–2020 (Table 3), of which more than 11,000 MW 
are under construction and will be commissioned by 2012. Managing an expansion program 
that is expected to increase the system capacity more than threefold over 10 years (2006–2015) 
inevitably will be a major challenge. Under the 6th PDMP, EVN will undertake about half of the 
projected capacity additions in hydropower, coal, and natural gas. Joint ventures between state-
owned enterprises and private sector investors, and by private sector investors without state 
participation, will make the remaining investments.  
 
14.  About $23 billion in investment is required for the sector in 2006–2010. EVN will provide 
$14 billion (about $9 billion from internal cash generation and $5 billion in net borrowings), while 
other investors will cover the remaining $9 billion. A similar level of investment is expected for 
2011–2015. The availability of concessional official development assistance and domestic funds 
through the Government is limited. Thus, EVN increasingly is borrowing on commercial terms 
from export credit agencies and ADB’s ordinary capital resources (OCR). EVN plans to raise 
funds in international capital markets through a series of US dollar bonds during 2006–2010. 
EVN is already raising financing from the domestic market by issuing bonds denominated in 
Vietnamese Dong.  
 
a.  Maintaining Financial Viability of the Power Sector 
15.  EVN’s operations have been profitable, and it has financed the rapid expansion of the 
Viet Nam’s electricity sector without significant fiscal subsidies. The main financial performance 
indicators,  such  as  debt  service  cover  ratio,  self  financing  ratio,  debt-equity  ratio,  and 
receivables, have been maintained. The average end user tariff has been maintained at $0.052 
per kWh from 2003 to 2006. Due to EVN’s increasing debt financing and financial obligations for 
power purchases from independent power producers (IPP) on a take-or-pay terms,14 sustained 
tariff increases are required to maintain adequate levels of debt service and self-financing of 
new investments. In this context, MOI submitted to the Government a tariff increase to ensure 
EVN’s  financial  performance  indicators  are  maintained.  The  Government  approved  a  tariff 
increase of 8.8% in October 2006 and this took effect as of 1 January 2007. EVN’s financial 
performance and projection is in Appendix 2, while the projected financial statements are in 
Supplementary Appendix B.

state and non–state sectors to the sector and to ensure the legitimate rights of the consumers 
and the investors in the sector.” Further, the law states that the Government monopoly in the

c.  Government Road Map for Sector Reforms  
17.  The Road Map for Electricity Market Establishment and Development, approved by the 
Prime Minister, envisages a phased approach to sector reforms. During the first phase of the 
power market’s development, the competition will be only among the power plants. A pilot 
internal power market limited to EVN power plants was initiated in January 2007. Beginning in 
2009, a single buyer will act as an intermediary between the power plants and distribution 
companies. The single buyer will sell electricity to distribution companies and large consumers 
at regulated prices. The next phase of the power market development will entail the wholesale 
competitive market, where sellers (power plants) and buyers (distribution companies and large 
consumers) will compete in a power pool. The final stage will be retail competition, which will 
allow  retail  consumers  to  choose  their  supplier.  An  important  issue  is  the  degree  of 
independence of the single buyer and the system operator from the rest of EVN, which could 
continue to own and control a significant stake in partially corporatized power plants during the 
early stage of reform. This will require transparent rules for market operation, for dispatching of 
power plants, and for settlement, as well as appropriate regulatory oversight. The ongoing ADB 
TA to the Electricity Regulator16 will address these strategic issues. 
 
d.  Regulation of the Electricity Sector 
18.  The main functions of the electricity regulator are to (i) issue licenses to sector entities, 
and to enforce the license conditions; (ii) advise the minister on market structure and industry 
restructuring policy; (iii) establish the tariff-setting principals, including transfer pricing between 
sector  entities;  (iv)  develop  tariffs  for  regulated  activities;  (v)  approve  power  purchase 
agreements of the single buyer (EVN or a new entity to be establish after 2009); (vi) ensure the 
procurement  of  adequate  new  generation  and  transmission  capacity;  (vii)  monitor  the 
implementation progress of new generation and transmission projects; and (viii) monitor the 
functioning of power market. The regulator’s role also involves ensuring proper performance of 
key market institutions, such as the single buyer, the system operator, and the transmission 
company, in providing equal opportunities to the power plants taking part in the power market. 
ADB, together with Agence Française De Développement (AFD) and the World Bank, are 
assisting MOI in developing instruments, such as transparent rules for market operation and 
dispatch of power plants and settlements, as well as appropriate regulatory oversight that would 
address the concerns of the private sector.

lowest in the world.17 Viet Nam is a signatory18 to the Kyoto Protocol,19 which aims to reduce

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
28.  The Project comprises the construction of the 1,000 MW Mong Duong 1 Thermal Power 
Plant, the power complex that will have an installed generating capacity of 2,000 MW or 2,200

growing electricity demand in an environmentally sustainable manner; (ii) help increase the

season imbalance of hydropower plants; and (iii) facilitate, through the inclusion of common 
facilities to be shared by the Mong Duong 1 and 2 thermal power projects, the construction of

for appropriate capacity building in number of areas, and incorporate all necessary environment 
and social safeguards.

C.  Technical Justification  
31.  Available  clean  coal  technologies  evaluated  for  the  Project  include  conventional 
pulverized coal-fueled boilers, super critical boilers (operating at much higher temperatures and 
pressures),  integrated  coal  gasification  combined  cycle  units,  and  CFB  boilers.  The  TA 
consultants found the CFB technology to be optimal for the following reasons: 
(i)  Pulverized coal-fueled boilers require sulfur and nitrous dioxide cleaning equipment 
(not necessary for CFB technology) that would be more expensive in capital cost and 
operations for the type of coal to be used.  
(ii)  Although super critical boiler technology is well-established, it requires high-quality 
and costly manufacturing technology, and is not suitable for the relatively poor-
quality domestic anthracite available. It is more suited for countries with a much 
higher cost of delivered coal, and an established advanced industrial technology 
base to support it during plant operation and maintenance. 
(iii)  Integrated  coal  gasification  combined  cycle  technology  is  still  largely  in  the 
development stage, and the first commercial plants are generally at the prototype 
stage. 
 
32.  Based  on  this  assessment,  unit  size  of  250  MW  CFB  boilers, 20  matched  with 
conventional 500 MW turbo-generators, were found optimally suited to burn the generally poor-
quality  and  expected  variability  of  fuel  (blended  coal  mixture)  available  for  the  Project. 
Worldwide, CFB technology is still evolving for boiler sizes above 250 MW. As the long-term 
reliability of the 250 MW boilers has been established, this boiler size is being considered for the 
Project. Thus, the Project requires four 250 MW CFB boilers and two 500 MW turbines. To 
satisfy  permissible  national  air  emission  limits,21 the  CFB  boilers  will  be  equipped  with 
electrostatic precipitators to limit particulate emission. Moreover, sulfur dioxide emissions will be 
limited by injecting limestone into the boiler during combustion, and nitrous oxide emissions will

33.  EVN will use new but proven CFB technology, which enables the efficient use of poor-
quality and waste coal by blending it with better coal. If not used, the waste coal will be burned 
inefficiently on a small scale with fewer environmental mitigation measures, or it will remain 
around the coal mines contributing to atmospheric dust and environmental pollution.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
59.  The Project is included in the Government's 5th and 6th PDMP. The long-term system 
optimization under the 6th PDMP confirms that the Project is part of the least-cost schedule of 
capacity addition to meet the growing electricity demand of the country. Detailed economic and 
financial  analyses,  conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB  guidelines,  are  in  Supplementary 
Appendix F.  
 
A.  Economic Analysis 
60.  The economic viability of the Project was examined based on incremental costs incurred 
and benefits accrued to the society. This analysis was conducted by comparing the societal 
costs and benefits of the "with Project" scenario against the "without Project" scenario. All costs 
and benefits were evaluated based on a domestic price numeraire. EVN estimated the Project's 
costs, which ADB staff checked and verified. Staff made adjustments to bring these estimated 
costs to include social costs by applying shadow exchange rate factor (SERF).26 
 
61.  The costs to the society are the investment and operating costs of the Project, as well as 
the environmental mitigating costs. Investment costs, in turn, consist of (i) equipment costs; (ii) 
construction costs; and (iii) engineering, administrative, and management costs of power plant 
construction. Fuel (coal and limestone) and related costs account for a significant part of the 
operating costs. While the total cost takes into account physical contingencies, it excludes 
interest during the construction and price contingencies.  
 
62.  The economic value of electricity generated by the Project is measured by using the 
costs  to  the  society  of  not  having  the  Project  (the  so-called  avoided  costs).  These  costs 
comprise  the  costs  of  suboptimal  operation  of  thermal  power  plants  to  partially  offset  the 
shortage  of  electricity  resulting  from  not  having  the  Project,  and  the  costs  to  consumers 
(industrial, residential, commercial, and rural) due to no electricity. In other words, the societal 
benefits of the Project is the sum of two components: the non-incremental benefits accrued 
through  savings  by  not  having  to  run  other  thermal  power  plants  suboptimally;  and  the 
incremental benefits accrued to the consumers by having sufficient supply of electricity to meet 
their needs, thus avoiding load shedding27 and associated economic losses. 
 
63.  A detailed analysis (Appendix 10) demonstrates that the demand for electricity will grow 
quickly between 2005 and 2025, particularly in the northern region where the Project is to be 
constructed. The analysis also confirms that the Project, which is scheduled to be added to the 
grid in 2011, is part of a rigorously planned schedule of capacity additions to the power system 
during 2006–2025. Economic valuation of costs and benefits of the Project, with extensive 
sensitivity analysis, has confirmed the economic robustness of the Mong Duong power complex. 
The Project yields an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 22.5% and corresponding net 
present  value  (NPV)  of  $846.6  million  over  its  economic  life  of  30  years  (Supplementary 
Appendix F).

B.  Financial Analysis 
 
64.  An  additional  analysis  was  carried  out  to  examine  the  possible  impacts  of  a  large 
investment such as this Project on the country’s debt sustainability and other macroeconomic 
indicators. The analysis was based on an ADB OCR assessment paper, draft 2007–2010 CSP, 
and the calculation of foreign exchange flow of the Project. This analysis showed that the 
project investment does not alter the debt sustainability of the country in the medium to long 
term, because the disbursement of the loan is within the OCR limit. Since more than 70% of the 
ADB loan will be awarded under an EPC contract, the Project will not have significant effects on 
supply or consumer sectors, and does not suggest excessive inflation. Further, the Project will 
generate sufficient revenue to repay its associated loans. The financial evaluation of the Project 
was undertaken in real terms using constant 2006 prices. The project cost estimates and 
financial projections in nominal terms were converted to real terms by adjusting the projected 
effects of foreign and domestic inflation, and currency fluctuations. The energy generated by the 
Project was conservatively valued at $0.041 per kWh, based on the price paid by EVN to IPPs. 
The  cost  estimates  in  Appendix  5  are  used  for  the  financial  analysis,  excluding  price 
contingencies and interest during construction. The financial internal rate of return (FIRR), 
computed after tax, is 6.59%. This compares favorably with the weighted average cost of capital 
(WACC), also computed after tax, of 2.85%. The Project is considered financially viable and 
sustainable. Sensitivity analysis indicates the FIRR remains robust under adverse conditions. 
The detailed financial analysis is in Appendix 11. 
 
C.  Impacts 
65.  Land Acquisition and Resettlement. A full resettlement plan, covering the plant site, 
ash pond, discharge channel, and workers’ site, has been prepared in accordance with the legal 
framework of Viet Nam and ADB’s policies. The resettlement plan has been disclosed to the 
people affected by the Project. Land acquisition requirements have been minimized by selecting 
a project site at the mouth of the Mong Duong River. The area is used for coal transport and 
storage; and has been heavily modified from its natural state with earthmoving, areas of fill, and 
changes to waterway and hydrological conditions. The project area is generally hilly with some 
tree  plantations.  Based  on  the  preliminary  design,  about  148  ha  of  land  will  be  acquired 
permanently. Most of the affected land is degraded forest land (83 ha), fish ponds (41 ha), and 
industrial land (24 ha). 
 
66.  Khe Guia Lake, about 10 km from the project site, initially was to provide fresh water 
supply to the Project. Late in project preparation, however, the Quang Ning People’s Committee 
decided that fresh water supply for the Project will be sourced from the Thac Thay River. A 
small reservoir will have to be built to provide fresh water during plant operation. Due to the late 
decision of the provincial authorities, EVN had difficulty preparing a detail resettlement plan, as 
well as determining the line route of the water pipeline. In addition, this will have to be agreed 
with the provincial authorities. ADB, after a due diligence assessment of the proposed site, 
determined that no one lived in the area because it was hilly. A few people cut trees in the area 
to supply timber as props for the coal mines, and as sleepers for the railway. In accordance with 
an agreement with EVN, a full resettlement plan based on the framework will be prepared 
(Supplementary Appendix G) for the reservoir, if necessary, and disclosed before approval of 
the second loan.  
 
67.  The  objective  of  the  resettlement  plan  is  to  ensure  that  impacts  are  avoided  or 
minimized. If involuntary resettlement is unavoidable, the plan is to provide compensation, 
assistance, and socioeconomic support programs to ensure that the people affected by the 
Project will be able to restore or improve their socioeconomic status. Resettlement impacts will 
comprise the following: (i) 37 households will be affected, of which 32 will be required to

19 
relocate;  (ii)  eight  coal  transportation  companies  and  one  tree  plantation  company  will  be 
required to move; (iii) one construction company will be partially affected; (iv) land of four farm 
owners (timber, fishpond, and fruit trees) will be acquired; and (v) employees of farm owners 
(80) and companies (306) might lose their jobs temporarily during the transition period when the 
companies  reorganize  their  activities.  The  Project  also  might  affect  fisherfolk  as  the  EIA 
predicted a possible loss of revenue from fishing and aquaculture during construction of the 
plant. A suitable compensation plan has been prepared and included in the resettlement plan, 
which will be updated during detailed design and disclosed to project-affected persons. The 
compensation payments will be adjusted upwards, if necessary. The summary resettlement plan 
is in Appendix 12, while the full resettlement plan is in Supplementary Appendix H. A public 
information booklet (Annex 8 to Supplementary Appendix H) also was prepared and disclosed 
to the people affected by the Project.  
 
68.  Environment. The Mong Duong complex has been classified as a Category A project in 
accordance  with  the  ADB’s  Operations  Manual  (OM)  and  Bank  Policies  (BP)  FI/BP: 
Environmental Considerations in ADB Operations. Further, an EIA has been prepared for the 
project to meet the requirements of the ADB’s Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003). 
The EIA describes the environmental baseline conditions in the project area, and records the 
results  of  a  comprehensive  examination  of  the  potential  impacts  of  the  Project  on  the 
surrounding  natural  and  socioeconomic  environment.  A  one-time  air  quality  sampling  and 
analysis at five locations showed that concentrations of total suspended particulate exceeded 
national air quality standards. As the limited sampling results cannot be used to determine the 
status of air quality in an airshed, additional monitoring will be done during construction, in 
accordance with the World Bank’s Environmental, Health and Safety Guidelines. A core part of 
the EIA is an EMP, which documents the environmental mitigation and monitoring activities that 
will be implemented throughout preconstruction, construction, and operation of the Project. The 
EMP contains a discussion of the institutional arrangements that will apply to its implementation, 
and the institutional strengthening activities that will be undertaken to ensure agencies involved 
in implementation have adequate resources to fulfill their obligations under the plan. The EMP 
also  contains  detailed  cost  estimates  for  its  implementation.  Several  public  stakeholder 
consultations have been held. A survey on the Project and its potential social and environmental 
benefits as well as the views expressed by the project affected people, have been incorporated 
in the final EIA. The summary EIA was prepared and provided to the Government on 14 August 
2006. 
 
69.  Important issues that have been considered in the EIA include the effects of the Project 
on ambient air, and surface water and groundwater quality. A range of technical mitigation and 
pollution control measures, as well as capacity building, has been recommended for inclusion in 
the Project to reduce these impacts to acceptable levels. Moreover, a detailed monitoring 
program has been developed for ambient air and water quality. The effect of the Project on 
mangrove ecosystems also has been considered, and a program of mangrove replanting to 
offset identified biodiversity losses is included in the Project. These have been discussed with 
EVN and TPPMU1, which they have agreed to implement the measures indicated in the EMP. 
The EIA for the transmission lines that will transmit the power generated by the power plant is 
included in a previous approved loan in 2005. 
 
70.  Social and Gender. The Project is formulated to minimize potential social and gender 
risks, and such impacts have been assessed along with other potential risks. The social impact 
of  the  Project  involves  (i)  loss  of  livelihood, (ii)  land  acquisition,  (iii)  forest  and  mangrove 
encroachment, (iv) affect on aquatic resources, and (v) incremental pollution from coal dust. The 
social analysis indicates that the Project will not affect any ethnic minority households. Thus, 
ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples is not triggered. The Project could increase the potential 
for the spread of HIV/AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases due to the influx of workers

20    
during construction. However, this potential will be mitigated or minimized through a program to 
increase awareness and provide preventive measures for the local communities and workforce. 
The Project will address social impact through capacity building of the stakeholders at the 
grassroots level to increase the role of local communities in implementing and monitoring the 
resettlement  activities,  occupational  health  and  safety  program,  HIV/AIDS,  and  trafficking 
awareness campaign. The Summary of Poverty Reduction and Gender Strategy (Appendix 13) 
include measures to facilitate participation of the affected people and relevant stakeholders. The 
increased capability and awareness of men and women commune leaders, men and women 
representatives from affected households and the implementing agency will enable effective 
implementation of the resettlement plan, EIA, occupational health and safety program, and 
HIV/AIDS.  
 
71.  Occupational Health and Safety Management System. Health-related hazards in the 
project area primarily include respiratory problems, lung disease, and eyes and nose infections. 
In Mong Duong, 68% of children are reported to suffer from respiratory diseases, while 50% 
have  nose  and  eyes  infection.  The  Project  will  establish  an  Occupational  Health  and 
Management System (OHSMS) that will include raising awareness and training employees and 
residents to change the prevailing safety and health protection cultures, particularly burning of 
coal in households for cooking and heating. The OHSMS will explore options for fuel switching 
by the households and include features for continual feedback and self-improvement. A safety 
and health committee will be established with active participation of men and women workers. 
Surveillance of the workers health system will be incorporated. 
 
D.  Risks 
 
72.  The financial and economic viability of the Project depends on the implementation of the 
other  components  of  the  power  system’s  expansion  in  northern  Viet  Nam.  These  include 
investments in the transmission network and supplementary power generation capacity to avoid 
overloading of facilities and suboptimal generation operation. EVN and the private sector are 
making  concerted  efforts  to  mobilize  financing  and  implement  these  projects  successfully. 
Therefore, these risks are not considered serious, because (i) some new generation plants are 
under construction in northern Viet Nam, and (ii) ADB and the World Bank are financing the 
high-voltage  transmission  and  distribution  networks.  Through  the  proposed  power  sector 
reforms, the Government is taking steps to create an enabling environment that removes entry 
barriers for third parties. These reforms are on track, with MOI taking the lead in promoting the 
regulatory framework to accelerate the reforms. Further, the Project, along with domestic private 
sector investors, is facilitating the mobilization of private sector investment in generation. 
 
73.  The financial projections of EVN have been prepared on the following assumptions: (i) 
operational efficiency continues to improve, (ii) proceeds continue to be received from EVN’s 
equitization (partial privatization) program, and (iii) tariff increases are implemented in a timely 
manner to ensure EVN’s prudent compliance with financial covenants. The projected reduction 
in system losses from 12.1% to 10.1 % in 2011 will improve EVN’s operational efficiency. If the 
assumptions on fuel costs, cost of purchased power from IPPs, and the shift in the consumer 
mix deteriorate, tariffs would have to be adjusted. The sensitivity of financial ratios (used as 
financial covenants) to the adverse movements of these assumptions was assessed, which is 
deemed important in the context of the proposed single buyer market structure. The Electricity 
Regulator, established in 2005 under the Electricity Law, continues to build its capacity to set 
tariffs transparently on sound economic and financial grounds, which will mitigate this risk 
significantly. The World Bank is assisting the Electricity Regulator in developing the framework 
tariff-setting mechanisms.

21 
74.  Private investment in new projects and EVN’s ongoing program equitization existing 
power plants is envisaged to increase. The financial proceeds from selling equity stakes will 
also contribute significantly to EVN’s cash flows. As such, EVN’s financials are assumed to be 
at risk if the equitization program is unsuccessful. However, this may not be the case as the 
Prime Minister approved EVN’s equitization plan in April 2007 to complete the equitization 
process by end 2008..As the power market in Viet Nam is relatively underdeveloped, ADB, 
AFD, and the World Bank will establish regulatory mechanisms through ongoing TAs that 
encourage the private sector to take the market and regulatory risks that arise in the electricity 
market. 
 
75.  Social and resettlement risks involve the possibility that compensation, resettlement, and 
income restoration measures might not be delivered as agreed, thereby disadvantaging affected 
people and possibly delaying the start of civil works. This risk is being mitigated by ensuring that 
the consultants and TPPMU1 have appropriate and competent specialists to assist in updating 
and implementing the resettlement plan. TPPMU1 will also engage an independent monitoring 
organization to supervise implementation. The establishment of the OHSMS for surveillance of 
workers  health,  together  with  efficient  awareness  and  training  programs,  will  mitigate 
occupational health risks. The diversion of the river and discharge channel will affect marine 
fisheries  and  mangrove  areas,  reducing  the  livelihood  potential  of  the  fisherfolk.  The 
resettlement plan incorporates compensation arrangements for loss of fisheries, while the EIA 
will incorporate a community-based mitigation plan for fishery and community involvement in 
replanting of mangroves. The continuation of economic growth of 7.5% is assumed. Slower 
growth would reduce the rate of growth in electricity demand. However, the analysis of risks 
shows that the economic viability of the investment program remains robust even with adverse 
changes in anticipated economic growth, and in other key risk factors and assumptions.  
 
76.  Another possible risk is that a second PFR and second loan will not be made. In that 
scenario, the Project could be completed under financing provided by parties that do not require 
that  ADB’s  safeguard  policies  be  applied  to  the  Project.  ADB’s  strong  and  continuing 
relationship with EVN and the Government mitigates this risk considerably.

FINANCIAL PERFORMANCE AND PROJECTIONS OF VIET NAM ELECTRICITY  
 
A.  General Overview 
 
1.  Vietnam Electricity (EVN) is a large and complex organization whose core business is 
the  supply  of  electricity  throughout  Viet  Nam.  However,  EVN  also  has  some  non-core 
businesses engaged in manufacturing and other industries, the largest being EVN Telecoms. 
EVN  is  organized  into  a  number  of  different  types  of  entities,  including  15  independent 
accounting units, 20 dependent accounting units, 6 administrative units, 14 construction and 
project management units, and some subsidiaries and joint ventures in which EVN controls 
more than 50% of the voting rights. In early 2007, the Government decided to convert EVN into 
a holding company called Viet Nam Electricity (EVN) and most of its operating entities will be 
converted to limited liability companies with EVN retaining whole or partial ownership. 
2.  EVN was created in 1995 as a vertically integrated entity responsible for the electricity 
sector  in  Viet  Nam.  EVN’s  operations  have  been  profitable  and  it  has  financed  the  rapid 
expansion  of  the  electricity  sector  without  significant  fiscal  subsidies.  The  key  financial 
performance indicators, such as debt service coverage ratio (DSCR), self-financing ratio (SFR), 
and receivables, have been maintained at prudential limits. Meanwhile, the average end user 
tariff  has  been  maintained  at  around  Vietnamese  Dong  (D)  853  per  kilowatt-hour  (kWh) 
($0.053/kWh). However, to satisfy future demand for electricity resulting from rapid economic 
growth, EVN will need to make considerable investments in generation, transmission, and 
distribution. A substantial portion of these investments will be financed by debt, sustained tariff 
increases are required to maintain adequate levels of debt service and self financing of these 
new investments. 
B.  Historical Performance 
3.  EVN's electricity sales have doubled in 2000–2005, representing average annual growth 
of 15.2%. Although the average tariffs net of sales taxes have increased only marginally from 
D660/kWh  ($0.047/kWh)  in  2000  to  D810/kWh  ($0.05/kWh)  by  2005,  EVN’s  revenue  has 
increased from D16.8 trillion ($1,160 million) in 2000 to D38.0 trillion ($2,400 million) in 2005. 
Further, its net profit nearly tripled from D888 billion ($62 million) in 2000 to D2.8 trillion (about 
$180 million) in 2005.  
4.  In recent loans approved by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and World Bank, the 
Banks and the Government of Viet Nam (the Government) agreed to adopt new financial 
covenants based on (i) consolidated EVN financial statements; and (ii) EVN's overall financial 
viability  and  performance,  rather  than  arbitrarily  setting  tariffs  in  foreign  currency.  These 
covenants were included in two recently approved loans1 as follows: (i) self-financing ratio 
(SFR) of 25%, (ii) debt service coverage ratio (DSCR) of 1.5, and (iii) debt-equity ratio of 70:30. 
EVN complied with these covenants during 2000 to  2005. However, there has been a reduction 
in EVN’s net cash flow and operating profits due to absence of tariff increases from 2003 -2006. 
This has reduced the SFR to 25% in 2005 from 70% in 2003, and DSCR to 2.0 in 2005 from 5.3 
in 2003. This is expected to be reversed with tariff increases of 8.8% effective from 1 January 
2007 and a further 5% increase in July 2008. The retail tariffs beyond 2009 will be adjusted to 
reflect the market prices in the competitive generation market to be set up in 2009.

1.  Sales and Income 
5.  The  fastest  growth  in  electricity  sales  has  been  in  the  industrial  sector,  where  the 
average annual growth was between 17% and 18% during 2000-2005 period. As a result, the 
industrial sector’s share of overall demand increased from 40% in 2000 to 45% in 2005. The 
household sector also has shown considerable annual growth, averaging 12% over the past 12 
years. This is a result of increasing demand by existing customers and additional demand from 
new connections, as more households are connected to the electricity supply system.  
6.  More than 90% of EVN’s revenue comes from electricity sales, with only 8% from other 
services and products. Income from the telecommunications business, at D378 billion in 2005,is  
less than 1% of EVN’s total income. However, EVN Telecoms has its own ambitious investment 
and expansion plans, particularly regarding the development of its mobile telephone service and 
is expected to be a major contributor to EVN’s consolidated revenues from 2007 onwards. 
2.   Production and Supply 
7.  In  2005,  EVN  produced  more  than  52.3  terawatt-hours  (TWh)  from  its  own  power 
stations, and purchased an additional 12.5 TWh from independent power producers (IPP). The 
largest source of power was hydroelectricity (33%), followed by gas turbines (28%), fuel oil 
(23%), and coal-fired power stations (16%). IPPs (including imports) account for 24% of total 
supply. However, electricity from hydropower has declined by 7% due to adverse hydrological 
conditions, resulting in a deficit that has been made up primarily from gas-fired power stations 
and an increase in power purchases from IPPs. As the gas-fired power plants are in the south, 
power is transmitted to the north at a high cost to meet the power shortages. This has resulted n 
higher operating expenses and lower operating profits in 2005 compared to 2004.  
3.  Operating Costs 
8.  Depreciation is one of the largest operating costs for EVN, accounting for over 30% of its 
operating costs. Under the Vietnamese Accounting System (VAS), depreciation periods are 
generally shorter than those allowed under International Accounting Standards, which accounts 
for the relatively high levels of depreciation. EVN also relies on these high levels of depreciation 
to fund its future capital expenditure program and to improve the SFR. The other major cost 
items are fuel costs for thermal power stations and purchased electricity from IPPs. EVN uses 
lower calorific value (4,000–5,500 kilocalories per kilogram [kcal/kg] of domestic anthracite coal 
for power generation. Generally, this coal has little value unless it is washed. The higher-quality 
anthracite coal is exported as coking coal. For this type of coal, EVN’s cost currently varies from 
$24–$28/ton but future prices will increase. Gas prices are denominated in US dollars, based on 
agreed volume and long-term contracts. In recent months, new agreements have been linked to 
a fuel price index due to increased drilling costs. EVN does not receive any direct operating 
subsidies from the Government to cover its operating costs. However, the Government does 
inject additional capital to help finance specific investments, such as the Son La hydropower 
plant and provides access to lower interest loans from state-owned banks.  
4.  Capital Expenditure 
9.  During  2000–2005,  EVN  invested  more  than  D81.5 trillion  in  new  capital  works. 
Approximately 45% of this expenditure has been financed by taking out additional long-term 
loans, while the remainder was financed from its own resources (50%) and capital injections by 
the Government (5%). Outstanding long-term loans have increased from about D26.9 trillion in 
2000 to more than D53.7 trillion by 2005.

2.  Operating Expenses 
11.  The operating expenses of EVN largely depend on the plant mix used for meeting the 
forecast demand and fuel price projections. The plant mix for 2006–2011 is based on the

different types of coal mines and a transparent coal market in Viet Nam make identifying any 
implicit subsidy to EVN through the discounted coal prices difficult. Gas prices are based on the 
production share agreements signed with the international gas field developers.

D.  Future Developments 
15.  EVN is moving away from its traditional role of generating its own electricity to one in 
which it buys a considerable amount of electricity from third parties, and then transmits and 
distributes it to end users. There is a strong case for splitting EVN into a number of independent 
entities, such as transmission companies, distribution companies, and power stations (where 
the State’s shares in these entities are held by a Holding Company), as a way of increasing 
transparency in the functioning of the market. The Government has approved a plan for EVN to 
equitize (i.e., partially privatize) minority stakes in most power generation plants and regional 
power companies. As of July 2007, three power plants, including a 1,000 MW coal power plant, 
a provincial power distribution utility, and 17 non-core businesses had been equitized. The 
liabilities associated with the equitized entities were transferred to the equalized entity, and the 
par value was computed net of the liabilities. The cash proceeds from the equalization will 
improve EVN’s cash flow. However, the debt-equity ratio of EVN as a consolidated entity will not 
be affected, as EVN intends to retain a majority stake in the equalized entities.  
16.  As a means of attracting non-EVN investments to the sector, EVN is planning to form 
several joint ventures for the construction and operation of some power stations. The liabilities 
of new power plants to be developed as joint ventures between EVN and other parties—where 
EVN is expected to be the majority shareholder—are consolidated in the financial projections. In 
the case of joint ventures where EVN is the minority shareholder, EVN’s share of the expected 
profit from these entities appears on its balance sheet as profit from other activities in the 
projections. 
 
E.  Proposed Covenants 
17.  With EVN’s increasing indebtedness, a maximum long-term debt-equity ratio of 70:30 
and a minimum DSCR of 1.5 are proposed as financial covenants to ensure that the company’s 
debt level and its debt service capacity remain within prudential limits. Although the debt-equity 
ratio is increasing steadily and DCSR is decreasing, they remain within these limits during the 
forecast period, except in 2010 when the debt-equity ratio exceeds 70:30. A minimum SFR of 
25% is imposed to ensure that EVN generates adequate cash flows to finance a reasonable 
portion of the capital investments, thereby keeping the company's leverage within prudential 
limits. These covenants were included in a loan approved in 2004 and another approved in 
2005 (Footnote 1), and EVN complied comfortably with them. Whether EVN will comply with 
loan covenants in 2006 and future years depends largely on future tariff increases and fuel price 
fluctuations.

1.  The  Project  will  cause  the  loss  of  approximately  41  hectares  (ha)  of  mangrove

contribute to the ongoing degradation of mangrove ecosystems in northern Viet Nam. Mangrove 
ecosystems in this region already are threatened by resource extraction, as well as land use 
change  for  aquaculture,  industrial,  and  infrastructure  uses.  To  offset  the  expected  loss  of 
mangrove  ecosystems,  a  mangrove  management  and  monitoring  plan  (MMMP)  has  been 
prepared, and is included in the environmental impact assessment (EIA). The central feature of 
the MMMP is the replanting of up to 100 ha of mangrove vegetation in the Bai Tu Long National 
Park, which is approximately 18 kilometers west of the project site. The park, which is in the 
same  bio-geographic  zone  as  the  project  site,  was  selected  as  the  preferred  location  for 
replanting activities in part because of the security of future land tenure and use. It also offers 
the  potential  to  involve  the  provincial  Forest  Protection  Department  and  National  Park 
Management Board in the replanting activities. Thus, institutional strengthening is provided to 
these organizations.   
 
2.  The Project will also cause the loss of more than 35 ha of plantation forestry ecosystems

comprise  predominantly  exotic  Acacia  and  Eucalypt  forestry  vegetation,  which  has  high 
socioeconomic value for households and businesses in the project area, but relatively low 
biodiversity value. Measures to address losses of plantation forestry ecosystems are contained 
in the resettlement plan and a terrestrial ecology management and monitoring plan. An outline is 
provided in Supplementary Appendix G. The key measures that will be implemented include (i) 
minimization  of  the  project  footprint  during  detailed  design  activities,  (ii)  protection  and 
monitoring of areas of retained vegetation on site, (iii) compensation for loss of forestry crops, 
(iv) allocation of new areas of forestry land, and (v) livelihood stabilization assistance measures 
for households affected by forestry losses caused by the Project.

PROJECT AND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT ASSESSMENT OF VIET NAM ELECTRICITY 
AND THERMAL POWER PROJECT MANAGEMENT UNIT 1 
A.  General Overview 
1.  Viet Nam Electricity (EVN) is the Executing Agency for the Mong Duong 1 Thermal Power 
Project, while the Thermal Power Project Management Unit 1 (TPPMU1) is the Implementing 
Agency. This appendix assesses the capability of EVN and TPPMU1 to handle the proposed 
Project.  
 
2.  Government-owned  EVN  is  responsible  for  (i)  producing,  transmitting,  and  supplying 
electricity;  (ii)  designing  and  constructing  relevant  projects;  (iii)  manufacturing  electrical 
equipment; and (iv) providing related services to customers. TPPMU1, which is fully owned by 
EVN, is authorized to manage and organize thermal power plant projects in northern Viet Nam. 
EVN and TPPMU1 have experience in implementing major projects funded by international 
funding agencies. Since its inception in 1995, TPPMU1 has managed one large project funded 
by Japan Bank for International Cooperation and several other projects funded by EVN and 
local banks.  
 
B.  Flow of Funds 
3.  Asian Development Bank (ADB) and EVN are the financiers of the Project. ADB will 
finance equipment, civil works, international and national consultants, contingencies, interest 
during construction, and commitment fee. However, ADB will not finance any taxes and duties 
related  to  these  expenditures.  EVN  will  finance  local  overhead,  project  preparation, 
administration, resettlement, and all taxes and duties. Under the ADB loan, foreign and local 
equipment will be paid directly to the contractors. For expenditures not covered by the ADB 
loan, TPPMU1 will establish a separate bank account for receiving necessary fund transfers 
from EVN.  
 
C.  Staffing and Accounting Policies, Budgeting System, and Payments  
4.  TPPMU1  has  about  100  employees,  with  specialists  in  engineering,  environment, 
resettlement, economics, and finance. TPPMU1 reported having sufficient staff to carry out all 
its tasks and meet deadlines. Most of the staff has Vietnamese degrees in accounting, finance, 
economics,  or  similar  discipline.  Although  no  specific  regular  training  program  exists  for 
TPPMU1 finance staff, most have been trained to record the transactions in implementing the 
projects. The Government requires EVN to comply with the Vietnamese Accounting Standards 
(VAS). Accordingly, EVN has adopted, for all its business units, uniform accounting policies and 
procedures, documentation, and charts of accounts suitable to power sector. The consolidated 
accounts are converted later to International Accounting Standards (IAS). 
 
5.  EVN and TPPMU1 have proven experience in the efficient management, budgeting, and 
fund disbursement in past projects. Budgets for physical and financial targets were prepared in 
sufficient detail. The project management and accounting staff compare invoice quantities, 
prices, and terms with those indicated on the purchase order, and with the records of goods and 
services actually received, and check the accuracy of calculations.  
 
D.  Policies and Procedures, Cash and Bank 
6.  EVN follows VAS, and has an adequate policy and procedures manual to guide activities 
and ensure staff accountability. In March 1998, ADB worked with Ministry of Finance (MOF) in 
preparing a “Manual on Project Accounting and Disbursement Procedures” for ADB financed

projects. EVN uses this manual, and updates it as necessary in accordance with the changes 
required by ADB and the Government. The procedures exist to ensure that only authorized 
persons of the (MOF) can alter or establish a new accounting principle, policy, or procedure to 
be used by EVN. 
 
7.  TPPMU1 uses EVN’s new computerized finance system (developed with World Bank 
funding) to record all transactions. This is a sophisticated system that allows the input of invoice 
details and authorizes payments. Summary information is transferred electronically to EVN 
headquarters  monthly.  The  adequacy  of  the  existing  accounting  policies  and  financial 
procedures has been assessed1 in light of the Vietnamese Accounting System (VAS) and IAS. 
A comparison of major accounting policies between VAS and IAS shows that, for most part, the 
Business Accounting Policies promulgated by MOF for all Vietnamese enterprises and adopted 
by EVN conforms with IAS. However, certain policies are still at variance with IAS, particularly: 
accounting for (i) foreign currency and translation; (ii) fixed asset capitalization; (iii) fixed asset 
depreciable amount, rate, and method; (iv) amortization of intangible assets and organization 
expenses; (v) long-term investment; (vi) reporting requirement; (vii) accounting frameworks; and 
(viii) audit.   
 
8.  The  director  and  the  deputy  director  of  finance  of  TPPMU1  are  the  authorized 
signatories on the bank accounts. EVN has its own established procedures and mechanisms for 
collecting money from end users in payment for their electricity bills. The deputy head of finance 
and the appropriate TPPMU1 project manager reconcile the bank statements every month. The 
TPPMU1 director and the finance director review and approve all unusual items on the bank 
reconciliation. 
 
E.  Safeguard Over Assets and Reporting 
9.  TPPMU1  is  responsible  only  for  implementing  projects;  the  completed  projects  are 
handed over to another EVN entity to operate and maintain. EVN follows the Government 
system of adequate safeguards to protect assets from fraud, waste, abuse, and corruption. Viet 
Nam law expects people who suspect others of participating in corrupt practices to report them 
to  the  “appropriate”  authorities.  Measures  taken  include  the  issue  of  the  Anti-corruption 
Ordinance dated 26 February 1998. Solutions for preventing, detecting, and enforcing penalties 
for corruption are also included. This ordinance—coupled with the strictness of law enforcement 
agencies in recent corruption cases—has restored some confidence in the law and justice 
systems regarding anticorruption measures. The director of TPPMU1 must approve all additions 
or amendments to TPPMU1’s payroll.  
 
10.  EVN and TPPMU1 are able to maintain separate accounts for the Project. TPPMU1, 
through EVN, will submit quarterly progress reports to ADB.2 The reports should provide a 
narrative of (i) progress made during the quarter, (ii) changes in the implementation schedule, 
(iii) problems or difficulties encountered, and (iv) the work to be carried out in the next period. 
TPPMU1 should be able to prepare these financial reports automatically from their finance 
system, though some assistance probably will be required initially to ensure the reports are 
providing the necessary information, and that all the information balances.

F.  Internal Audit and External Audit 
12.  Independent auditors audit the financial statements of EVN and TPPMU1 annually. 
Since 1999, their audits have not been delayed. The audit of EVN was conducted mostly in 
accordance with the International Standards on Auditing for public institutions.  
 
13.  During 2001, EVN discovered that certain costs were included improperly as part of 
construction  in  progress  as  of  31  December  2000.  This  led  to  a  restatement  of  financial 
statements for 2000. In 2002, EVN revalued some of its power station assets, which increased 
their value by about D3,000 billion. The external auditors noted that this revaluation violated IAS 
principles, because any revaluation should be applied to the whole class of assets, not just a 
subset. Otherwise, the auditors have not made any significant qualification to EVN’s accounts 
during the past 5 years. According to the external auditors, EVN and all of its units generally 
keep their accounts properly, consistent with Viet Nam’s laws and regulations. Further, the 
auditors commented that the units of EVN have improved how quickly they produce their 
accounts over the last few years. In addition, the auditors reported that fewer management 
letters have noted improved procedures in recent years with fewer significant internal control 
issues identified, while the number of qualified audit opinions has declined.  
 
14.  In March 1998, EVN established its Internal Audit Department, which is headed by a 
chief of internal audit and supported by five professional accountants. EVN relies heavily on 
direct  supervision,  detailed  reporting,  and  authorization  from  top  management  for  internal 
control.  This  internal  audit  ensures  proper  checks  and  balances,  and  delineation  of 
responsibilities. Internal reviews are conducted as follows: (i) the Inspection Department, with a 
team of selected representatives from the various business units, conducts inspections on 
compliance with EVN policies and Government rules and regulations; (ii) an ad hoc inspection 
team selected by the director general conducts inspections for certain activities of business 
units; (iii) the Finance and Accounting Department team handles accounting supervision; and 
(iv)  the  Management  Board  and  the  Control  Section  of  the  Board  carry  out  inspections. 
Inspections are conducted based on Government guidelines, and focus on the reviews of plans, 
expenditures, contracts, and compliance. TPPMU1 has not been subject to an internal audit 
report. 
 
15.  The consolidated financial accounts of EVN are submitted to the Ministry of Industry, 
MOF, and Tax Department for review and approval. MOF audits are used to determine tax 
liabilities, scheduled payments of “state-rented” capital, and other financial matters. MOF’s 
revision committee has the right to audit any part of EVN, though TPPMU1 has not been subject 
to such an audit. EVN prepared financial statements of its previous projects in accordance with 
VAS. The TPPMU1 system prepares simple financial statements monthly, and this reporting 
should be adopted to report on this Project. Although trying to link physical progress with 
financial progress could be useful in predicting estimated completion date and total cost, this is 
not  really  necessary.  Most  contracts  by  TPPMU1  are  fixed-cost  contracts,  which  pay  a 
contractor a predetermined amount when it completes a specific amount of physical work.

16.  Financial  reports  clearly  compare  the  actual  expenditures  with  budgeted  and 
programmed allocations. Automated accounting systems prepare the financial reports using 
spreadsheets  and  other  computerized  programs.  Under  the  current  accounting  system,  all 
EVN’s dependent units, including TPPMU1, prepare and submit monthly accounting, financial 
statements, and other financial reports to EVN. However, independent accounting units only 
submit  their  reports  quarterly.  EVN’s  Accounting  Department  reviews  the  reports  before 
submission to EVN’s Management Board for consolidation.  
 
17.  The  computerized  accounting  system  EVN  is  using  is  still  being  evaluated,  and 
improvements are being introduced as necessary. Financial statements prepared by TPPMU1 
focus on maintaining separate records and accounts adequately. It could identify (i) goods and 
services financed from the proceeds of the loan, (ii) other financing resources received, (iii)

funds. TPPMU1 has used the computerized financial management system, which can produce 
the necessary project financial reports. EVN’s and TPPMU1’s finance and account staffs have 
been  trained  adequately  to  maintain  the  systems.  The  management  organization  and 
processing system has safeguarded the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of the data.  
 
18.  EVN will need to prepare terms of reference acceptable to ADB for the annual project 
audit. The auditing company should inspect and substantiate the accuracy and sustainability of 
accounting documents and figures, as well as other accounting finalization reports kept by EVN 
and TPPMU1. 
 
G.  Conclusion and Recommendations 
19.  In general, TPPMU1 appears to be a fit and proper body to administer the proposed 
ADB loan for the Mong Duong I Project. While the assessment identified no significant weak 
points, two minor points were identified. First, although the computer system is backed up 
regularly, the backups themselves are stored on TPPMU1’s premises, rather than on a remote 
site. Second, as TPPMU1 has no specific experience administering an ADB loan, the staff will 
require training in ADB procedures. However, they should have little difficulty in understanding 
and implementing these. If somebody from another EVN project management board with ADB 
loan experience (e.g., Northern Power Project Management Board) could share the details of 
administering the loan, it would be useful.
