3.  System Planning Methodology 
7.  System  planning  is  formulated  based  on  the  set  of  candidate  plants,  taking  into 
consideration constraints that reflect the fuel availability and system reliability criteria (power 
plant outage, maintenance requirement, transmission line reliability rule, etc.). Two gas supply 
possibilities were considered: 14 billion cubic meters and 10 billion cubic meters per year during 
2020–2025. The two most important reliability criteria are (i) the loss of load expectation (LOLE) 
criteria applied to the whole generation system, and (ii) the rule n-1 applied to the transmission 
capability. The LOLE criterion stipulates that the expected loss of load should not exceed 24 
hours per year, expressed in hours LOLE < 24 per year. The n-1 rule takes care of the situation 
when one circuit of the double-circuit 500 kV line is not functioning, while the remaining system 
will still work stably. 
 
8.  System optimization was carried out using software based on dynamic programming 
optimization  to  find  out  the  expansion  plan  with  lowest  total  discounted  costs.  Apart  from 
demand data, other important inputs for optimization are (i) technical and financial economic 
data  of  all  generation  sources,  fuel  types,  fuel  price,  investment  cost,  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M) cost, efficiency, load factor, failure frequences, etc.; (ii) investment cost, 
voltage, length, O&M cost, losses, failure frequences, etc., for transmission lines; and (iii) fuel 
supply availability or limitation, and fuel costs. Investment costs of generation and transmission 
candidates are taken from prefeasibility studies, if available, or estimated based on international 
and  national  experiences.  Fuel  costs  are  forecasted  taking  into  account  international 
projections. O&M costs are based on the domestic and international practices. The costs are 
economic costs without provision for taxes. Environmental costs are not included.

Project can help meet the economy’s increasing demand for electrical power from 2010 on, and can minimize the 
country’s dependence on imported power. At the regional level, the Project can meet the demand of the economic 
triangle of Hanoi–Hai Phong–Quang Ninh. At the provincial level, the Project will use local coal supply and promote 
the development of industries—coal mining and limestone quarrying—thereby creating jobs for local residents.   
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Following Asian Development Bank’s Enhanced Poverty Reduction Strategy (December 2004), projects classified as 
general intervention no longer require project-level poverty assessment. The following is a brief description of the 
affected people, and the likely impact of the Project. The project site is in one ward (Mong Duong) and two communes 
(Duong Huy, Cam Hai). All the affected households in the project area are Kinh. The Project does not affect any ethnic 
minority households. Economic activities in the project area vary by location. Coal mining, shipbuilding, cement 
production, fisheries, and seafood processing are the main activities of Cam Pha town, while coal industry is the main 
driver of the economy for Mong Duong ward. The economy in the project area relies mainly on forestry and various 
industries, rather than agriculture. Tree plantation for timber, aquaculture, and fisheries are the main sources of 
income at the commune level.  
 
The main project impacts are loss of jobs; land acquisition (refer to resettlement plan); and loss of forest, mangrove, 
and aquatic resources (refer to the environmental impact assessment). The Project will acquire forest plantation land 
from forest plantation cooperatives. Large land owners own the cooperatives, which have permanent wage workers. 
Similarly, land from a big aquaculture pond will be acquired. The Mong Duong power plant will negatively impact the 
water quality and biological resources of marine coastal environment. The diversion of Mong Duong River and cooling 
water discharge channel to Cam Hai commune would have adverse affect on fishery and mangroves (refer to EIA). 
The resettlement plan, gender strategy, and environment management plan of the Project include strategies to 
address these impacts on the local environment and livelihood of the people. 
 
Health. Coal mining in Cam Pha Town has been polluting the air and environment through discharge of wastewater, 
dust etc. The widespread diseases in the project area related to pollution are (i) respiratory problems, (ii) lung disease, 
and (iii) eyes and nose infection. In Mong Duong, 68% of children suffer from respiratory diseases, and 50% suffer 
from nose and eyes infections. These diseases are linked mainly to the coal dust generated by coal transportation. A 
substantial proportion of the coal mine workers have contracted silicosis. VINACOAL has a program to give its most 
severely affected workers access to silicosis treatment. Coal dust-related health problems of local people might 
increase because of additional dust generated by the Project. During project implementation, occupational health 
measures will be developed to minimize health problems related to coal dust pollution for the workers.

66  Appendix 13 
 
HIV/AIDS data indicates significant incidence in Cam Pha town. Some cases of HIV are reported in Mong Duong 
ward. The project province, Quang Ninh, has 133 kilometre (km) of national border with the People’s Republic of 
China, with international border gates and unofficial crossroads through which goods and people traverse every day. 
In addition, the province has a 250 km sea border, which allows various forms of marine moving, including human 
trafficking. During construction, camps for construction workers and offices will be established in the project sites. A 
workforce of 4,500 is expected on site during construction. The labor camp will be set up near to the project sites. In 
addition, permanent workers camps will be established for the Mong Duong project. The presence of large number 
labor camps in pre- and post-construction phases poses a potential risk of HIV/AIDS and human trafficking in the 
project area. In the project province, government and nongovernment organizations (NGO) have been engaged in 
implementing HIV/AIDS and human trafficking-related programs. From January 1999 to February 2003, Quang Ninh 
provincial police dealt with 91 cases of human trafficking. From January 2005, the International Organization of 
Migration, in partnership with the Women’s Union, implemented an 18-month Counter Trafficking Project in Quang 
Ninh Province, Viet Nam. A national program on AIDS is implemented in the province. In addition, several NGOs are 
present in Cam Pha, and have programs to prevent the spread of HIV/AIDS.  
 
Under the proposed Project, HIV/AIDs and human trafficking awareness program will be undertaken during pre- and 
post-construction phases in the project area. The experience and lessons from the existing program in the province 
will be incorporated in designing the awareness program. In addition, the awareness program will be coordinated as 
appropriate with the existing programs of various agencies.  
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
Stakeholder analysis as part of the consultation process was conducted at the commune and district level during 
preparation of the feasibility study of the Project.   
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
The Project will emphasize participatory processes in implementing the resettlement plan, environmental impact 
assessment plan, occupational health action plan, and awareness program on human trafficking and HIV/AIDS. 
Commune-level resettlement committees will include representatives of affected people, mass organizations (women’s 
union, youth union), and relevant commune-level officials to address resettlement issues. The Government Decree 79 
(Grassroots  Democracy)  encourages  community  participation.  The  commune-level  resettlement  committees  will 
facilitate effective implementation of Decree 79. The occupational health and safety plan and awareness programs on 
HIV/AIDS and human trafficking will facilitate active community involvement in implementing the activities (see gender 
strategy below).  
 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
In the project area, the main economic activities include forest plantation, fishery, and industry. Gender analyses 
include households affected by land acquisition and loss of fisheries. Women work in aquaculture and forest plantation 
as wage workers. In marine fishery, women accompany men out to sea, and they play significant role in all fishing 
activities: catching fish, preparing nets, harvesting, cleaning, and selling fish. Women also are involved in white worm 
collection in the coastal area. Women in the forest plantation are involved in planting, taking care of trees, and cutting 
trees. In aquaculture, women are responsible for feeding fish and taking care of the pond. To ensure the participation 
women in project activities during implementation of the resettlement plan, as well as HIV/AIDS, human trafficking, 
and health-related programs, the following measures are included in the gender strategy: 
(i)  At project inception, a capacity building training program on resettlement activities will be designed for 
women and men commune officials, and women and men from affected households. The training will 
also include representatives from line agencies, and representatives from the commune Women’s Union 
and  Youth  Union  involved  in  resettlement  committees.  The  training  will  include  information  on 
resettlement activities, compensation, and the impact of the Project on livelihood activities related to the 
loss of jobs and fisheries. The objective of the training is to provide affected communities with an 
understanding resettlement issues and the environmental impact of the Project on fisheries, mangroves, 
and health. The training will facilitate effective implementation of the resettlement plan, and will help in 
addressing of environment-related impacts on livelihoods.

Appendix 13  67 
(ii)  The district resettlement committees will include women representatives from the district Women’s 
Union. Commune-level resettlement committees will include the commune Women’s Union and Youth 
Union to represent the interests of women in the affected households to assist resettlement activities.  
(iii)  Separate consultations will be held with the men and women workers from the forest plantation, coal 
companies, aquaculture industry, and households regarding compensation and deployment in forest 
plantation and aquaculture industry in another location. Project monitoring will include information on 
deployment of women workers. Similarly, separate consultation will be held with men and women from 
fisherfolk households to determine relevant compensation for loss of fisheries and developing fish culture 
and plantation of mangrove-related activities. 
(iv)  Specific attention will be given to complaints and grievances by women.  
(v)  Thermal Power Project Management Unit 1 will create a specific awareness activities for men and 
women workers about occupational health issues linked to the power plant project. Occupational health 
and safety awareness will include identification of gender-related occupation health issues and safety 
measures.  
(vi)  TPPMU1 will conduct an HIV/AIDS and anti-trafficking awareness campaign involving communities 
during project construction and implementation. Women’s Union, Youth Union, health workers, female 
community leaders and members, and women from affected households will be involved in implementing 
the campaign. 
(vii)  As per the Labor Code (as amended in 2002), all employment for the Project will respect Government 
commitments  to  gender  equity,  including  (i)  deployment  of  women  workers  in  forest  plantation, 
aquaculture industry, and coal companies; (ii) ensuring that no child will be used; and (iii) ensuring the 
same wages are paid to men and women for work of equal value. 
(viii)  The Executing Agency will create a specific occupational health and safety awareness training program 
for men and women workers. A gender-related occupation health and safety management system will be 
established. The Health and Safety Committee will include women representatives as members. 
(ix)  Gender sensitization training related to resettlement and occupational health will be provided for relevant 
staff from the Electricity of Vietnam, TPPMU1, and resettlement committees.   
(x)  A national consultant on social development and gender will be included in the consulting services for 
the implementation of the gender strategy. The terms of reference for the social development and 
gender consultants are included in the consulting services.
